paragraphs.text: If Abbott is serious about tackling terrorism, cutting foreign aid is the worst way to go about it.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: In conjunction with the joint military action against Islamic State (Isis), Tony Abbott has pledged $5m in humanitarian aid for Iraq on his recent surprise visit to Baghdad
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: don't be fooled by the government's apparent show of generosity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Australia isn't giving any more to foreign aid than it was before
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is giving significantly less
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is vitally important that we don't stop talking about recent cuts to foreign aid
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The government's mid-year economic and fiscal outlook has reduced the foreign aid budget to the lowest levels in Australian history
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Foreign aid spending has been cut by almost $3.7bn over four years
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: In addition to the $7.6bn already cut in May's federal budget, foreign aid has been cut by one quarter
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the government is serious about tackling terrorist threats and defending "universal values"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: cutting off foreign aid to programmes that provide education, reduce poverty and improve gender equality is one of the worst ways to go about it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Save Australian Aid campaign states that $11bn in foreign aid - the amount cut from the foreign aid budget in the past year - is the equivalent of 2 million children who may not be able to enrol in school, 1.4 million births without a birth attendant, 3.7 million children who may not receive vaccinations, 4.7 million people who will have reduced access to safe water, and almost 22 million people with reduced assistance in emergency situations
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: These cuts further perpetuate the idea that Australia is not a team player, a notion fuelled by our past behaviour towards our neighbours, and our recent denials of international obligations towards asylum seekers and climate change
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In addition to the cuts in the Myefo, Australia backed out of commitments made to tax justice in the recent G20 summit
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It is estimated that developing nations lose $160bn per year to corporate tax dodging; an amount that would end world hunger three times over
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The G20 commitment, Abbott said, was "about the countries of the world, the people of the world, receiving the tax benefits that are their due and it's needed so that governments can fund the infrastructure and the services that people expect and deserve."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: As the host of the G20, backing out of this commitment not only damages our international credibility, but also has a huge impact on the developing world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The foreign aid cuts are irresponsible, but not surprising
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cutting the aid budget sends a clear message to our developing neighbours that Australia won't lend a helping hand unless it's in our own best interest
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: our politicians seem to forget that there is something in it for us, and not only in Iraq
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Aid is much more than a humanitarian gesture
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it's a tool for regional development, trust and cooperation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Foreign aid programmes promote stability through education and equality, in turn reducing conflict
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As an added bonus, foreign aid and sustainable development programmes create stronger economies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which in turn create opportunities at home and abroad
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Poverty breeds hopelessness and despair
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: which are both contributing factors to extremist behaviour
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Foreign aid is not the only factor in answering this issue
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it's more than a step in the right direction
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Higher levels of foreign aid have the potential not to only alleviate extreme poverty in our region, but to raise international opinion of Australia as a fair country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A recent study examining the effects of foreign aid on foreign public opinion found that US aid programmes targeting HIV/Aids have improved perceptions of the US among the public in recipient countries
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Australia would reap these benefits as a side effect of foreign aid, saving the millions of dollars set aside to "stop the boats" and wage a "war on terror"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But our government has, predictably, made yet another irresponsible decision with untold repercussions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: two innocent people died in Martin Place on 16 December in what has been labelled an act of terror
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: a reduction of this size in the foreign aid budget will result in the unnecessary deaths of hundreds across the globe due to reduced access to vital services
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The high priority the Abbott government has placed on security doesn't come cheap, with funds for anti-terrorism programmes costing billions of dollars
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Wouldn't this money be better spent reducing inequality, poverty, and conflict?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Shouldn't we be stopping the problem at the source, not trying to cure the symptoms?
